repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of - Economic
            Recovery and Post-Reunification Economic Recovery Credits;
            Congo, Republic of - Post-Conflict Economic Rehabilitation
            and Economic Recovery Credits

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings of the Project Performance
            Assessment Report (PPAR) generally concur with the
            Implementation Completion Report (ICR) ratings, except in
            the following instances: ratings for the Assessment of the
            Economic Recovery Credit Project are as follows: outcome
            (ICR highly satisfactory, PPAR unsatisfactory); bank
            performance (ICR satisfactory, PPAR moderately
            unsatisfactory); borrower performance (ICR highly
            satisfactory, PPAR moderately unsatisfactory). Ratings for
            the Assessment of the Post-Reunification Economic Recovery
            Credit Project are as follows: outcome (ICR unsatisfactory,
            PPAR unsatisfactory); borrower and bank performance (ICR
            unsatisfactory, PPAR moderately unsatisfactory).Ratings for
            the Assessment of the Post-Conflict Economic Rehabilitation
            Credit Project are as follows: outcome (ICR satisfactory,
            PPAR unsatisfactory); bank performance (ICR satisfactory,
            PPAR unsatisfactory); borrower performance (ICR
            satisfactory, PPAR unsatisfactory). Ratings for the
            Assessment of the Economic Recovery Credit Project are as
            follows: outcome (ICR unsatisfactory, PPAR unsatisfactory);
            borrower and bank performance (ICR moderately
            unsatisfactory, PPAR unsatisfactory). Some lessons learned
            included:  deep reforms changing the patterns of governance
            and public sector management require adequate preparation,
            including political economy assessment, consensus building
            effort and wide political and social ownership. In the
            absence of such thorough preparation, the likelihood of
            success is low, irrespective of potentially huge long-run
            gains for the country and society. In the post-conflict
            environment, a development policy operation (DPO) instrument
            can be effective if the reform program is well calibrated to
            a context of weak technical capacity and multiple
            priorities. In both countries, and for each operation,
            ownership of reforms was permanently elusive, and was only
            assured fleetingly by the lure of arrears clearance or debt
            relief. Ownership of reforms by respective governments
            followed a pattern of temporary commitment to reforms for
            immediate returns. Incentives to governments, leadership and
            ground conditions lacked for a successful pursuit of the
            ambitious reform agenda in both counties.

repnme.cdata!:
Progress report to the Board of Executive
            Directors on the Implementation of the Management's
            action plan in response to the Democratic Republic of Congo
            inspection panel investigation report

abstracts.cdata!:
The present report is aimed at providing
            information to the Board regarding the progress in
            implementing the action plan proposed by management. The
            action plan is first presented in matrix form, and then an
            explanation is provided of progress under the four main
            action areas. Agreed actions are grouped around four major
            themes: (i) improving and scaling up work in the region on
            safeguards and sound environmental and social design and
            implementation of the portfolio; (ii) scaling up the work on
            indigenous peoples in DRC (Democratic Republic of Congo) and
            ensuring that the relevant safeguards are appropriately
            triggered; (iii) supporting the forest policy reform agenda
            in DRC, and scaling up the forestry work; and (iv) improving
            outreach and communications.

repnme.cdata!:
Republic of the Congo - Economic Recovery
            Operation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Republic of the Congo
            Economic Recovery Operation Project were as follows:
            outcomes were unsatisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was high, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: 1) the time
            to get long-gestating public management reforms designed and
            started is before substantial resources become available to
            the government; 2) it is unwise to rely excessively on
            reform champions; 3) proactive supervision, always
            important, is critical to support major reforms in a
            post-conflict country with weak accountability mechanisms;
            and 4) technical assistance is unlikely to be effective in
            the absence of adequate government arrangements to
            coordinate the reform program as a whole.

repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Republic of - Economic Recovery
            Credit Project : Update on the Program Document

abstracts.cdata!:
This note provides information on
            developments which took place since the Project Document
            (PGD), dated July 29, 2004 was distributed to the Board. The
            overall macroeconomic framework (Section III B in the PGD)
            has slightly improved, in particular, the projected annual
            growth of non-oil GDP over 2005-07 has been revised upwards,
            from 4.9 percent to 5.3 percent on account of the projected
            secondary effects of higher oil output, and prices. There
            has been significant progress with Paris Club creditors over
            a series of meetings, notably on October 13, and November
            16, 2004. On the whole, creditors were satisfied with the
            efforts made by the authorities, and agreed to meet with
            Congo authorities in December to negotiate a flow treatment
            on Naples terms (67 percent Net Present Value reduction)
            that will cover 100 percent of arrears, and debt service.

docna.cdata!:
Congo, Republic of - Economic Recovery
            Credit Project : Update on the Program Document

display_title.display_title:
Congo, Republic of - Economic
            Recovery Credit Project : Update on the Program Document

5392544.subtopic: Environmental Economics & Policies,Banks & Banking Reform,Public Sector Economics,National Governance,Strategic Debt Management

abstracts.cdata!:
This Economic Recovery Credit Project
            aims at helping Congo deepen its reform program, as it
            benefits from an early access to the Heavily Indebted Poor
            Countries (HIPC) Initiative. In particular, the project will
            help the country: a) enhance transparency in the oil sector,
            through the implementation of the action plan, devised after
            the audit of the accounts of the oil company; b) rationalize
            public investment, to ensure fiscal discipline, and
            accountability, and make it more consistent with the
            pro-poor, and pro-sustainable development goals of the
            Interim Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (I-PRSP); and, c)
            reduce domestic arrears in an orderly, and transparent
            manner. Although risks are significant, these must be
            balanced with the risks of inaction, which are considerable.
            Risks stemming from Congo's post-conflict context are
            being mitigated under a number of International Development
            Association (IDA) credits. Also, the project would increase
            the chances of access to the Poverty Reduction and Growth
            Facility (PRGF) and HIPC, allowing further consolidation of
            peace. The risk of weak implementation capacity is mitigated
            by the relatively simple design of the operation, and will
            be further mitigated by the appointment of a monitoring, and
            follow-up team in the Ministry of Finance, intensive project
            supervision, and technical assistance under other IDA credits.
